grep.-n: Prefix each line of output with the 1-based line number within its input file.
grep.-w:
Select only those lines containing matches that form whole words. The test is that
 the matching substring must either be at the beginning of the line, or preceded by
 a non-word constituent character. Similarly, it must be either at the end of the
 line or followed by a non-word constituent character. Word-constituent characters
 are letters, digits, and the underscore. This option has no effect if -x is also
 specified.
grep.-r:
Read all files under each directory, recursively, following symbolic links only if
 they are on the command line. Note that if no file operand is given, grep searches
 the working directory. This is equivalent to the -d recurse option.
grep.--include:
Search only files whose base name matches GLOB (using wildcard matching as
 described under --exclude).

Explanations about Options.-perm:
Any of the permission bits mode are set for the file. Symbolic modes are accepted
 in this form. You must specify `u', `g' or `o' if you use a symbolic mode. See
 the EXAMPLES section for some illustrative examples. If no permission bits in mode
 are set, this test matches any file (the idea here is to be consistent with the
 behaviour of -perm -000).
Explanations about Options.-mtime:
File's data was last modified n*24 hours ago. See the comments for -atime to
 understand how rounding affects the interpretation of file modification times.
Explanations about Options.-iname:
Like -name, but the match is case insensitive. For example, the patterns `fo*' and
 `F??' match the file names `Foo', `FOO', `foo', `fOo', etc. The pattern `*foo*`
 will also match a file called '.foobar'.

 they are on the command line. Note that if no file operand is given, grep searches
 the working directory. This is equivalent to the -d recurse option.
grep.--include:
Search only files whose base name matches GLOB (using wildcard matching as
 described under --exclude).

grep.-n: Prefix each line of output with the 1-based line number within its input file.
grep.-w:
Select only those lines containing matches that form whole words. The test is that
 the matching substring must either be at the beginning of the line, or preceded by
 a non-word constituent character. Similarly, it must be either at the end of the
 line or followed by a non-word constituent character. Word-constituent characters
 are letters, digits, and the underscore. This option has no effect if -x is also
 specified.
grep.-r:
Read all files under each directory, recursively, following symbolic links only if
 they are on the command line. Note that if no file operand is given, grep searches
 the working directory. This is equivalent to the -d recurse option.
grep.--include:
Search only files whose base name matches GLOB (using wildcard matching as
 described under --exclude).

Explanations about Options.-r: This tells rsync to copy directories recursively. See also --dirs (-d).
Explanations about Options.-n:
This makes rsync perform a trial run that doesn’t make any changes (and produces
 mostly the same output as a real run). It is most commonly used in combination
 with the -v, --verbose and/or -i, --itemize-changes options to see what an rsync
 command is going to do before one actually runs it.

grep.-n: Prefix each line of output with the 1-based line number within its input file.
grep.-w:
Select only those lines containing matches that form whole words. The test is that
 the matching substring must either be at the beginning of the line, or preceded by
 a non-word constituent character. Similarly, it must be either at the end of the
 line or followed by a non-word constituent character. Word-constituent characters
 are letters, digits, and the underscore. This option has no effect if -x is also
 specified.
grep.-r:
Read all files under each directory, recursively, following symbolic links only if
 they are on the command line. Note that if no file operand is given, grep searches
 the working directory. This is equivalent to the -d recurse option.
grep.--include:
Search only files whose base name matches GLOB (using wildcard matching as
 described under --exclude).

 interest for diagnostic purposes.

 source.

grep.-n: Prefix each line of output with the 1-based line number within its input file.
grep.-w:
Select only those lines containing matches that form whole words. The test is that
 the matching substring must either be at the beginning of the line, or preceded by
 a non-word constituent character. Similarly, it must be either at the end of the
 line or followed by a non-word constituent character. Word-constituent characters
 are letters, digits, and the underscore. This option has no effect if -x is also
 specified.
grep.-r:
Read all files under each directory, recursively, following symbolic links only if
 they are on the command line. Note that if no file operand is given, grep searches
 the working directory. This is equivalent to the -d recurse option.
grep.--include:
Search only files whose base name matches GLOB (using wildcard matching as
 described under --exclude).
